entry.title: Re: Story Reporting on PM forms - how do you do it?
entry.content:
Hi Kris, 

What I did in order to choose multiple templates in a single story report:

1. From Available data in Query Designer chose Performance Management > All Templates, tab Form Template

2. From Available data chose User, drag and drop in  the query to create the connection between the two data sources.

3.Select the fields with info needed for your report

4.When creating the table in the report page, create a Page Filter for Form Template Name. In this way you will be able to choose one or more Templates/Performance years/ that you would like to be visible in the report at this time.

Hope it helps.

Best regards,

Petya

entry.title: Re: Unable access to "Create Maintenance Notification" Ap...
entry.content:
To use this app, you’ll need to activate the 'Asset Management – Reactive Maintenance (BJH)'. This scope item enables the creation and processing of maintenance notifications and orders.
Make sure the user has the correct business role - SAP_BR_MAINTENANCE_TECHNICIAN assigned. This role includes access to the app and related functionalities.
Also, confirm the role includes the relevant catalog which is SAP_EAM_BC_MNTREQ_PROC_PC. - This catalog contains the tile for creating maintenance notifications.

entry.title: SAP Discovery Center Expands and Welcomes the SAP BTP Guidance Framework
entry.content:
We are excited to announce that SAP Discovery Center has expanded to include even more SAP Business Technology Platform expert insights and strategic guidance. The SAP BTP Guidance Framework has now found a new home in SAP Discovery Center.  
 
You have consistently praised SAP Discovery Center for being an excellent resource for all things SAP BTP. Including, BTP Service and AI Feature catalog info, cost estimations, and implementation guidance. Your feedback always remains the same – “It’s so nice to find all the info in one place.”. With your feedback in mind, we are excited to bring these two key resources closer together in one location.  
 
What does this mean for you? 
You might remember the previous SAP Discovery Center homepage, which welcomed you with four main tiles – Missions, Reference Architectures, SAP BTP Services, and SAP Business AI. What you will notice now is that the Reference Architectures tile has been replaced by a brand-new tile – SAP BTP Guidance Framework.  
 

 

Don’t worry, you can still easily find all reference architectures on the new SAP BTP Guidance Framework landing page. 
 
 
 
If you are new to the SAP BTP Guidance Framework, it provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. It houses expert-curated resources to help you make smart decisions and is tailored for architects, developers, and administrators.  
Some of the key resources you will find are: 
  • Methodologies 
  • Reference Architectures 
  • Guides 
If you want to learn more about the SAP BTP Guidance Framework and its offerings, please check out my other blog post – SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators where I explore the topic in much more detail. 
 
You Might Also be Interested In 
The Guidance Framework has also been presented as a live YouTube series with role-based episodes. Watch the recordings available on YouTube: 
  1. SAP BTP Guidance Framework Series: How-to Empower Architects, Developers, and Administrators 
  2. SAP BTP Guidance Framework: How-to Empower Developers 
  3. SAP BTP Guidance Framework: How-to Empower Administrators 
 
Stay Tuned 
We are currently driving a blog post series diving deeper into the SAP BTP Guidance Framework. Stay tuned for the next blog post covering the newest addition to the framework – SAP BTP AI Best Practices.

entry.title: Re: Enabling your workforce for the future with the new integrated learning experience
entry.content:
Hi @@notify

No Audit Trail Functionality in SAP SuccessFactors Learning – Library Status Changes

I would like to highlight a significant gap in the SAP SuccessFactors Learning Management System concerning the tracking of changes to library status (e.g., Active → Inactive → Active).

Currently, there is no standard report or functionality available to trace who made these changes and when they occurred. This lack of audit capability presents challenges for compliance, accountability, and overall transparency within the system.

Having the ability to track historical changes to the library status, including details such as the user who made the change and the timestamp, would greatly benefit the business. It would allow stakeholders to:

Understand the rationale behind status transitions,

Improve audit readiness,

Reduce errors or miscommunication, and

Enhance system governance and control.

We believe this feature would be a valuable enhancement to the Learning Management module and respectfully request that SAP consider providing an option to capture such historical data in future updates or via reporting capabilities.

We have submitted enhancement ticket with SAP.

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/353532

Thanks,

Panikar

entry.title: Sorting and Subtotal in Adobe LiveCycle designer public Cloud
entry.content:
Dear All,

Implementing complex logic like vendor-wise sorting and subtotaling in Adobe Forms becomes particularly challenging in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where no custom ABAP logic can be used. In On-Premise, we often rely on internal tables and logic in the interface program. But in SAP Public Cloud, we must rely entirely on Adobe LiveCycle Designer's JavaScript capabilities to achieve the same.

In this blog , I will share a solution where I achieved vendor-wise sorting and subtotaling directly inside Adobe LiveCycle Designer, using JavaScript in the Form Ready event, without any custom ABAP logic or BAdIs.

The Logic Below I inserted inside the subform. N number of tests and uploads have been done for this logic.

As you all know, field names and all names inside the hierarchy are case sensitive.

I used the vendor number for sorting, and I will hide that column in the table

""""""""""Form Ready Event """"""""" Java Script Code"""""""""""

 
function Comparator(column1) {
    return function(a, b) {
        if (a[column1] > b[column1]) return 1;  // this is the condition for Ascendening Order 
        if (a[column1] < b[column1]) return -1;
            return 0;
    };
}
// Create a New array for sorting the Main table and then Sort and Modify the same
var aRows = new Array();
 
// Get total number of Rows in the Array 
var nr =  Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1.all.length;
 
//start looping 
for (var i = 0; i < nr; i++) 
{
    aRows.push([xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].SupplierName").rawValue, 
                xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].partnername").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].Identification").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].HouseBank").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].PaymentRunDate").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].cheque").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].AccountingDocument").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].DocumentDate").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].reference").rawValue,
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].GrossAmount").rawValue,
        ]);
}
 
aRows.sort(Comparator(0)); // Here my vendor number is in the first column so put 0 in the comparator //if in the second column put as 1 like wise choose you column and set the number.
 
//Subtotal///////////////////////
var aRows_new = new Array();
var previous_pc = null;
var subtotalValue = 0;
var pushrecord = 0;
// Push first record value 
previous_pc = aRows[0][1];
 
 for (var i = 0; i < nr ; i++) 
{  
if ( aRows[i][1] !== previous_pc ){
aRows_new.push([ previous_pc , "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "Total",  subtotalValue ]);
 
pushrecord = pushrecord + 1;
  previous_pc = aRows[i][1];
  subtotalValue = aRows[i][9]; // the column which you are adding the subtotal
  aRows_new.push([ aRows[i][0],aRows[i][1],aRows[i][2],aRows[i][3],aRows[i][4],aRows[i][5],aRows[i][6],aRows[i][7],aRows[i][8],aRows[i][9] ]);     
}
 
 
else{
        subtotalValue  = parseFloat(subtotalValue) + parseFloat(aRows[i][9]);       
aRows_new.push([ aRows[i][0],aRows[i][1],aRows[i][2],aRows[i][3],aRows[i][4],aRows[i][5],aRows[i][6],aRows[i][7],aRows[i][8],aRows[i][9] ]);
}   
 
        if ( i == nr - 1  ) { 
  aRows_new.push([ previous_pc, "", "", "", "", "", "", "", "Total", subtotalValue ]); // this total is for printing table-wise.
  pushrecord = pushrecord + 1;     
        }     
}  
 
for (var i = 0 ; i < pushrecord; i++)
{ 
xfa.resolveNode( "Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1").instanceManager.addInstance( );
}
var nr_1 = aRows_new.length;
 
 
//After Sorting, Now modify the main table from New Array table values.
for (var i = 0; i < nr_1; i++) 
{
if ( aRows_new[i][8] == "Total" ){ 
xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"]").fillColor = "192,192,192";
xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].SupplierName").font.weight = "bold";
xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].SupplierName").presence = "invisible";
xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].reference").font.weight = "bold";
xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].GrossAmount").font.weight = "bold";
xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].GrossAmount").format.picture.value = "zzz,zzz,zzz,zz9.99";
}
 
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].SupplierName").rawValue = aRows_new[i][0]; 
                xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].partnername").rawValue = aRows_new[i][1];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].Identification").rawValue = aRows_new[i][2];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].HouseBank").rawValue = aRows_new[i][3];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].PaymentRunDate").rawValue = aRows_new[i][4];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].cheque").rawValue = aRows_new[i][5];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].AccountingDocument").rawValue = aRows_new[i][6];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].DocumentDate").rawValue = aRows_new[i][7];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].reference").rawValue   = aRows_new[i][8];
    xfa.resolveNode(" Form.SUPLR_01.Table1.Row1["+ i +"].GrossAmount").rawValue = aRows_new[i][9];
 
}
 
"""""""""""""""""End Code"""""""""""""""""""
Result :

 

Don't bother about the total, both are different screenshots.

Hope this will be helpful for you all.

Thank you 🙂

Regards,

 

Bijesh.

entry.title: How Retro Gamers Solved Time-Travel Debugging in 1995 (And Why Your Enterprise Debugger Still Can't)
entry.content:
A Tale of Two Debuggers

Scene 1: A modern enterprise developer in 2025, debugging a critical SAP integration. "If only I could go back in time and see what happened," they sigh, adding another log statement.

Scene 2: A 14-year-old in 2005, playing Super Mario on ZSNES. They press F1 to save state, die horribly, press F3 to load state, try a different approach. "Cool," they say, taking it completely for granted.

Welcome to the upside-down world where teenage gamers have better debugging tools than Fortune 500 companies.

TL;DR: github/ysichov/Smart-Debugger

https://github.com/ysichov/Smart-Debugger

The Secret That Wasn't a Secret

Here's what the retro computing community figured out decades ago:

Everything in a computer is deterministic except I/O.

That's it. That's the whole secret. Let me explain why this changes everything.

The Beautiful Math of Determinism

Same CPU state + Same memory + Same inputs = Same result
ALWAYS.

This means you don't need to record everything. You only need to record:

  • Initial state (once)
  • External inputs (keyboard, interrupts, timers)
  • I/O responses

For a Z80 system, that's maybe 100 bytes per second of recording. For an hour of debugging? About 360KB. That's smaller than a single Slack emoji.

The Timeline That Should Embarrass Us All

Let's put this in perspective with a side-by-side timeline:

🎮 Gaming/Emulator World vs 💼 Enterprise World

1997

  • 🎮 ZSNES: Save states introduced. Gamers can save/load any moment instantly
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Have you tried adding more print statements?"

1999

  • 🎮 Nesticle: Frame advance debugging. Step through games frame by frame
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Maybe we should standardize on log4j?"

2003

  • 🎮 FCEU: TAS* tools mainstream. Input recording, RAM watch, Lua scripting
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Distributed debugging is impossible"

2004

  • 🎮 MAME: Debugger with memory watchpoints, execution trace, state diffing
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Remote debugging sometimes works if you're lucky"

2006

  • 🎮 DeSmuME: Dual-screen debugging, touchscreen record/replay
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Have you tried turning on verbose logging?"

2010

  • 🎮 MAME: Full rewind feature. Go back in time at any moment
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Debugging microservices is hard"

2014

  • 🎮 BizHawk: Multi-system TAS suite. Deterministic replay across different CPUs
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Maybe we need more logs?"

2018

  • 🎮 RetroArch: Netplay with rollback, achievements system, shaders
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Debugging in production is scary"

2020

  • 🎮 TAS Bot: AI playing games frame-perfectly using debug tools
  • 💼 Enterprise: "We added structured logging!"

2023

  • 🎮 LibTAS: TAS tools for native Linux games, not just emulators
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Time-travel debugging? Sounds futuristic!"

2025

  • 🎮 Every emulator: Rewind, replay, Lua scripting, memory analysis standard
  • 💼 Enterprise: "Our new AI can analyze your logs!"

 

The Tragedy in One Image

Teenager in 2004: *casually rewinds Mega Man X, 
                   adjusts one frame, gets perfect run*

Senior Developer in 2025: "The bug only happens in production 
                          on Tuesdays. We'll never catch it."

What Makes This Hilarious/Sad

A Nintendo emulator from 1998 can:

 

  1. Run Super Mario
  2. Let you save at any millisecond
  3. Rewind time
  4. Record and replay any bug perfectly
  5. Show you every memory change in real-time

 

Your enterprise debugger can:

 

  1. Set breakpoints (sometimes)
  2. Print variables (if you're lucky)
  3. Crash (frequently)

 

Enter Tool-Assisted Speedrunning: Debugging as Art

TAS creators took these debugging tools and turned them into an art form. Watch this:

They're not just playing games. They're:

  • Analyzing frame-by-frame execution
  • Tracking memory corruption
  • Exploiting race conditions
  • Optimizing code paths

Sound familiar? That's literally what we do when debugging, except they have better tools.

The ABAP Revolution: Finally, Someone Gets It

Yurii Sychov looked at ABAP debugging and had a radical thought: "What if we just... did what emulators do?"

His Smart-Debugger implements what gamers take for granted:

  • Variable time travel
  • Execution recording
  • State comparison
  • Visual debugging

But here's where it gets REALLY interesting...

The Memory Revolution: It's 2025, Not 1975

Modern servers have TERABYTES of RAM. An ABAP variable? Maybe 1KB. Even a complex object graph? Perhaps 1MB.

This means we can store:

 

  • Every variable change
  • Every method call
  • Every execution path
  • Multiple complete runs

 

Do the math:

 

  • 1000 variables × 1KB each × 1000 changes = 1GB
  • Your server's RAM: 512GB
  • Percentage used: 0.2%

 

We're optimizing for constraints that haven't existed for 20 years.

The Graph Diff Revolution

Now here's where it gets wild. Since we can store everything, we can:

1. Record Multiple Executions

abap

" Run 1: Bug happens
execution_graph_1 = record_full_execution( buggy_input )

" Run 2: Bug doesn't happen  
execution_graph_2 = record_full_execution( good_input )

2. Build Execution Graphs

Graph 1 (Buggy):
main() → parse_input() → validate() → process() → CRASH
         ↓                ↓           ↓
      [user_id: 123]  [cache: empty] [null_ptr]

Graph 2 (Working):
main() → parse_input() → validate() → process() → success()
         ↓                ↓           ↓
      [user_id: 123]  [cache: valid] [object_ref]

3. Diff the Graphs

diff

@@ -15,7 +15,7 @@
 validate() {
   check_permission()
-  load_user_context()  // ← Returns null in buggy run
+  load_user_context()  // ← Returns valid object
   verify_data()
 }

Key difference: cache state at execution time
Buggy:   cache.contains(user_123) = false
Working: cache.contains(user_123) = true

4. Compare with Static Analysis

Your static analysis says load_user_context() can never return null. Your execution trace says it did. Boom. Bug found.

The AI Cherry on Top

Now feed this to an LLM with structured data:

{
  "execution_diff": {
    "divergence_point": "load_user_context()",
    "buggy_state": {"cache": "empty", "result": "null"},
    "working_state": {"cache": "valid", "result": "user_object"},
    "static_analysis": "method cannot return null"
  },
  "context": {
    "method_signature": "load_user_context(): User",
    "cache_invalidation_log": ["14:23:15 - cache cleared", 
                               "14:23:16 - request received"]
  }
}

Prompt: "Based on execution diff, identify root cause"

LLM: "Race condition detected: Cache was invalidated at 14:23:15, but the null check in load_user_context() only verifies if cache exists, not if the specific key is present. The 1-second window allows requests to hit empty cache."

Automated RCA achieved.

But Wait, What About Reality?

"Sure," you say, "but emulators work with closed systems. What about network calls? Databases? Microservices?"

Fair point! Modern systems have more non-determinism. But that's exactly why we need BETTER recording, not worse:

The I/O Boundary Principle Still Applies

" Instead of just keyboard input, modern I/O includes:
IO_Events = {
  network_responses,     " Record actual HTTP responses
  database_results,      " Record query results  
  timestamp_calls,       " Record time() returns
  random_values,         " Record RNG outputs
  thread_scheduling      " Record context switches
}

Yes, it's more complex than a NES emulator. But the principle remains: Record at the boundaries, replay deterministically.

The Call to Revolution

Here's what we should be demanding:

For Every Debugger:

 

  • Time travel (perfected in emulators since ~2010)
  • Deterministic replay (standard in TAS tools since 2004)
  • State diffing (TAS creators do this manually)
  • Execution graphs (we have the memory!)
  • Automatic RCA (we have the LLMs!)

 

The Technical Requirements:

 

  • Record I/O boundaries (a few KB/second)
  • Snapshot on demand (even 1GB is nothing)
  • Build execution graphs (basic CS)
  • Diff and analyze (solved problem)

 

Start Today

 

  1. If you use ABAP: Get Smart-Debugger now ^_^
  2. For other languages: Demand better tools
  3. For tool creators: Study emulators, not enterprise

 

The Future Is Already Here

It's just unevenly distributed. And ironically, it's been living in game emulators for 30 years.

Next time someone tells you time-travel debugging is "too hard" or "too expensive," show them a 15-year-old speedrunner casually rewinding time to manipulate RNG in Pokémon. Then ask them why enterprise software can't do the same.

Memory is cheap. CPU is fast. The algorithms are known. The only thing missing is the will to build it.

Welcome to 2025. It's time to debug like it.

Your debugger doesn't suck because it's hard to build. It sucks because the culture around it never thought like a gamer. Time to change that.

P.S. 🎮 TAS (Tool-Assisted Speedrun) A meticulously crafted playthrough of a video game using emulator tools like save states, slow motion, and frame-by-frame control. The goal: perfect execution—sometimes exploiting bugs—to achieve record-breaking performance or hilarious outcomes.

Alice Vinogradova is a Senior Software Engineer at Microsoft who thinks your debugger should be at least as good as a Super Nintendo emulator from 1998.

entry.title: Re: In F-36 Bill of exchange portfolio pop up not displaying
entry.content:
SAP only triggers the Bill Portfolio pop-up in transaction F-36 for company codes assigned to specific countries. These include:
- TR (Turkey)
- TH (Thailand)
- GR (Greece)
- RO (Romania)
- AE (United Arab Emirates)
- SA (Saudi Arabia)
- EG (Egypt)
If your company code is assigned to a country outside this list, the portfolio field will not appear; even if all other configuration steps are identical.

What You Can Do
- Double-check the country assignment in OX02
- Go to transaction OX02
- Select your company code
- Confirm the country key is one of the supported ones above
- Temporarily switch the country code for testing
- Change the country to TR or AE and retry F-36
- If the pop-up appears, you've confirmed it's a country-specific behavior
- Review table T045P
- Ensure your Bill of Exchange Portfolio is correctly defined there
- Use transaction OBB8 to maintain entries if needed

entry.title: SAP ERP, Private Edition, Transition Option: What Does it Mean for You as a Healthcare Customer?
entry.content:
SAP’s latest announcement about the SAP ERP, private edition, transition option (see Navigating Your RISE with SAP Journey: Updates for SAP ERP, Private Edition, Transition Option ) also marks an important moment for healthcare organizations, particularly for those reliant on SAP Patient Management (SAP IS-H). If you’re grappling with the complexity of cloud transformation while needing to maintain mission-critical, patient-centric operations, this new offering could be essential for your roadmap and RISE with SAP transformation journey.

What’s New? Supplementing Transformation Timelines for Large & Complex Customers

Healthcare institutions operating SAP Patient Management as part of their core IT landscape face unique challenges. Regulatory compliance, data sovereignty, data privacy, and the critical nature of hospital operations mean that transitions have to be thoroughly planned and be risk averse. While many industries can push for rapid digital transformation, the stakes are different in healthcare: every interruption potentially affects patient care.

That’s why SAP’s newly detailed SAP ERP, private edition, transition option as part of your RISE with SAP transformation journey could be a new opportunity for you. This offering creates a bridge, specifically for large and complex organizations, to go beyond the 2030 end-of-extended-maintenance date for SAP Business Suite 7, enabling a supported ERP environment until 2033 while providing a phased, structured path to SAP Cloud ERP or SAP Cloud ERP Private.

If you are running SAP Patient Management and are worried about the timeline to migrate to SAP Cloud ERP or SAP Cloud ERP Private, this transition option can help ensure business continuity and compliance.

Why Does This Matter for SAP Patient Management Customers?

1. Continuity for Core Healthcare Processes While Getting Extra Time for Your Cloud Transition

SAP IS-H underpins patient administration, billing, and integration with clinical workflows. The transition option means:

  • No disruption to SAP ERP and SAP Patient Management support up to 2033 for customers that move to SAP ERP, private edition, transition option by 2030.
  • Additional time for your cloud transformation to analyze and adapt custom developments, partner solutions, and integrations that are essential for your hospital’s daily operations.
  • Continued security patches and bug fixing for SAP ERP and SAP Patient Management until 2033 under the conditions of the transition option

2. Regulatory Security and Compliance

Managing sensitive information in healthcare demands rigorous safeguards. SAP ERP, private edition, delivers a managed cloud environment that allows you to maintain authority over your critical data and compliance activities. SAP also continues to provide legal changes for SAP ERP and SAP Patient Management until 2033 under the conditions of the transition option

3. Extra Time for Custom Ecosystem Adaptation

We understand that by being more than three decades in the market, SAP Patient Management has often been modified or extended with your own and partner solutions for scheduling, laboratory systems, telemedicine, and many more. This transition option gives your organization and your vendors and partners the necessary lead time to analyze, adapt, certify, and test your current and next-generation solutions alongside the evolving SAP offerings.

4. SAP Proactively Engages with the Partner Ecosystem for Upfront Preparation

Recognizing how healthcare organizations rely on interconnected partner and third-party solutions around SAP Patient Management, SAP has proactively reached out to its related partner ecosystem. This outreach ensures partners are aware of the transition option and can assess the potential impacts on their own offerings, resulting in

  • fewer surprises as timelines and technical requirements evolve;
  • an opportunity for additional assurances by third-party and partner solutions about their solutions remaining compatible during your transition;
  • an opportunity for your IT to innovate and adapt your healthcare-specific add-ons in line with SAP’s future strategic direction.

What is Required to Qualify for the Transition Option?

To benefit from this new transition option as a healthcare customer, you need to move to SAP ERP, private edition (on SAP HANA) before 31st of December 2030 and make sure that SAP Patient Management is already running on or migrated to this environment. Additionally, please make sure that your systems meet the prerequisites as outlined in SAP Note 3591251.

Please note that by signing up before the end of 2025, you secure commercial predictability and potentially save significantly compared to those who choose this migration path later.

What Should Healthcare Customers Do Now?

  1. Assess your SAP ERP and SAP Patient Management landscape, custom code, data, and connected solutions.
    Map your dependencies and check with your current and future partners how their services and products will support and handle the transition.
  2. Discuss with SAP and your partners.
    Open dialogue ensures you are informed of technical requirements, timelines, and potential migration steps.
  3. Design and prepare an actionable cloud transition plan. – Start the preparation of your systems, coding, integrations and data for the transformation.
    Taking early steps to move to SAP ERP, private edition ensures eligibility and gives you flexibility to pace your migration.
  4. Engage with the SAP Max Success Plan.
    This will support you not only technically but strategically, smoothing your journey to Cloud ERP when ready.

In Summary

Healthcare customers running SAP Patient Management now have an extended pathway forward to our modern Cloud ERP, with more time to comply, adapt, and maintain the highest standards in patient care and compliance. SAP’s active involvement with its partner ecosystem means you and your stakeholders can plan and navigate this journey together with stability and predictability

If your organization requires a tailored approach to digital transformation, reach out to SAP to discuss SAP ERP, private edition, transition option and ensure your hospital remains at the forefront of digital healthcare, securely and without compromise.

For more details, consult SAP Note 3591251 or your SAP representative.

Learn More

To learn more about this offering, please refer to the following resources:

  • Read Stefan Steinle’s SAP News article “Navigating Your RISE with SAP Journey: Updates for SAP ERP, private edition, transition option” at https://news.sap.com/?p=233946
  • Visit this SAP Support Portal page and SAP Note 3591251.
  • Reach out to your SAP account executive to discuss how the SAP ERP, private edition, transition option fits into your transformation strategy.
  • On the future direction of the SAP Services and Support portfolio, including the max success plan to be available in January 2026, see here.

entry.title: Re: When send a soap request via VBA error occurred: The...
entry.content:
Hi Joey,

Firstly, I strongly recommend you edit your post to remove/blur the URL and authentication information from your screenshot - you are potentially risking unwanted access...

Unfortunately, there is very little information to go on here. 

If you look up that error message, it seems to point to some authentication or permissions error.

I wonder if you are not properly managing your security sessions. If you are reusing sessions or not actively releasing them, you could be hitting some limits or using an expired session. This could account for the randomness of the error.

Here a few resources (some are for Cloud Integration or other products, but the concepts still apply: 

Good Blog about session handling: https://blogs.sap.com/2017/07/17/cloud-integration-how-to-configure-session-handling-in-integration-flow/

SAP Note 3201227  - 3201227 - Best practices for security session handling for API caller calling an ABAP system

Session Handling – be mindful of properly handling/using sessions to not trigger security countermeasures (DOS attacks, Cross-Site Scripting/forgery attacks, etc).

a.        Only create a security session when one is needed.

b.        Actively release/close the session when you are done with it (note 2760552 - Limitation of generation of HTTP security sessions)

  1. 3083426 - HTTP Security Sessions in ABAP Systems - Analysis and Logoff
  2. 1899896 - Security Sessions / Application Sessions - and timeouts
  3. 3319136 - No implicit security session creation for API callers calling an ABAP Cloud system as of 2402

Your development environment should have some debugging tools to help you get more details on the issue. You should be able to see the lower level communication (headers and payload and responses from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system to see the exact HTTP error messages you are getting).

Utilize the message monitoring apps in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to help debug your message: Message Monitoring

I would also recommend use a tool like SOAP UI to prototype your API calls before trying to integrate your app, that will give you more confidence that your communication/authentication, etc. is solid.

Thank you

Jerry

entry.title: SAP HANA Database Backup and Recover Process.
entry.content:
In any SAP landscape, system availability and data protection are critical to maintaining business operations and ensuring uninterrupted service delivery. SAP HANA, as an in-memory database, offers high-performance data processing but also introduces greater sensitivity to data loss due to its reliance on volatile memory. This makes having a comprehensive backup and recovery strategy not just important—but essential.

In this blog, we will delve into the key components of SAP HANA backup strategies, explore the various types of recovery methods, and walk through a real-world example of performing a point-in-time recovery (PITR) following accidental data deletion.

What we will Learn in This Blog

In today data-driven landscape, protecting critical information is paramount, especially for SAP HANA systems that run core business operations. This blog will guide through essential concepts and practical steps to design a reliable and efficient backup and recovery strategy for SAP HANA. Whether you're a system administrator, SAP BASIS consultant, IT manager, understanding these elements is crucial for ensuring data integrity and business continuity.

  • Types of Backups in SAP HANA: Understand the differences between Full, Incremental, and Differential backups, and when to use each type.
  • Backup Destinations and Tools: Explore backup storage options such as file system backups and the BACKINT interface for integration with third-party tools.
  • Recovery Options: Learn about various recovery strategies including full recovery, point-in-time recovery, and recovery to a specific data snapshot.
  • Best Practices and Optimization Tips: Discover strategies to improve backup reliability and reduce recovery time in critical scenarios.

By the end of this blog, we will gain a clear understanding of how to implement a proactive and effective backup policy tailored for SAP HANA systems ensuring resilience and uninterrupted business operations even in the face of unexpected failures.

Why Backup and Recovery Matter in SAP HANA

A well-defined backup strategy is essential in SAP HANA to safeguard critical business data, minimize downtime, and ensure compliance with regulatory and financial requirements. A robust backup and recovery plan helps maintain data integrity and provides resilience against various risks, including:

  • Hardware or storage failures
  • Software corruption
  • Logical data errors
  • Human errors, such as accidental deletions
  • Disasters, including data center outages or ransomware attacks

Types of Backups in SAP HANA - SAP HANA supports multiple backup types to protect data and ensure recoverability in case of system failures or data corruption. Below are the key backup types with brief descriptions:

  • Database Backup

Complete backup - A complete backup in SAP HANA typically refers to a Full Data Backup combined with Log Backups and Catalog Backups. This ensures that you can fully restore your system to a specific point in time in case of system failure or data corruption.

CMD: hdbsql -n <hostname>:<port> -u <user> -p <password> "BACKUP DATA USING FILE ('<backup_prefix>')"

Tenant DB backup
CMD: hdbsql -n <hostname>:<tenant_sql_port> -u <user> -p <password> "BACKUP DATA USING FILE ('<backup_prefix>')"

Incremental backup – An Incremental Backup in SAP HANA captures only the data that has changed since the last complete or incremental backup. It is more efficient in terms of storage and backup time compared to a full backup.

CMD: hdbsql -u <DB_USER> -p <PASSWORD> -i <Instance_No> -d <DB_SID>
  "BACKUP DATA FOR FULL SYSTEM INCREMENTAL USING FILE ('<BACKUP_PREFIX>')"
Tenant Database backup
CMD: hdbsql -n <host>:3<instance_no>13 -u <TENANT_USER> -p <PASSWORD> -d <TENANT_DB> \"BACKUP DATA INCREMENTAL USING FILE ('<BACKUP_PREFIX>')"

Differential Backup - A Differential Backup in SAP HANA captures all data that has changed since the last full data backup, regardless of any incremental backups taken in between.

CMD: hdbsql -n <host>:3<instance_no>15 -u <DB_USER> -p <PASSWORD> -d SYSTEMDB "BACKUP DATA FOR FULL SYSTEM DIFFERENTIAL USING FILE ('<BACKUP_PREFIX>')"
Tenant Database
CMD: hdbsql -n <host>:3<instance_no>13 -u <DB_USER> -p <PASSWORD> -d <TENANT_DB> "BACKUP DATA DIFFERENTIAL USING FILE ('<BACKUP_PREFIX>')"

  • Log Backup - SAP HANA uses log backups to persist transactional changes made in the in-memory database. These logs are essential for ensuring data integrity and enabling point-in-time recovery (PITR). Log backups allow the system to be restored up to the exact point before a failure. After restoring a data backup, HANA replays log backups to bring the system to the desired state. Additionally, if log backups are disabled or misconfigured, the log volume can fill up.
    • Automatic Log Backup: Default method where logs are backed up continuously to a configured location.
    • Manual Log Backup: Log backup triggered by an admin via SQL or GUI.
    • BACKINT Based Log Backup: Uses 3rd-party tools (e.g., Commvault, Veritas, NetBackup) via BACKINT API.
    • File-Based Log Backup: Logs written to a local or network file system directory.
  • Configuration Backup - Configuration Backup refers to saving the key configuration files and settings of an SAP HANA system, which are essential for system recovery, migration, or troubleshooting. Backup like HANA global configuration, SAP profiles, Parameters configuration, SSFS files backup and HANA backup configuration files.

Config Files Path-

/usr/sap/<SID>/SYS/profile/

/hana/shared/<SID>/global/hdb/custom/config/

/usr/sap/<SID>/SYS/global/hdb/custom/config/

SystemDb Command Line
SELECT * FROM M_INIFILE_CONTENTS;

EXPORT "SYS"."M_INIFILE_CONTENTS" AS CSV INTO '/hana/backup/config_backup/SystemDB' WITH REPLACE;

 

  • Storage Snapshots (External) - External Snapshots refer to storage-level (hardware or software-defined) point-in-time copies of SAP HANA volumes (data, log, shared). These are outside the SAP HANA database and managed by the storage subsystem, not by HANA itself.

Backup Destinations and Tools

SAP HANA supports multiple backup destinations including local file systems, NFS mounts, third-party tools via the BACKINT interface, and cloud storage such as Amazon S3 or Azure Blob. Backups can be managed using SAP HANA Studio, SAP HANA Cockpit, or SQL commands through hdbsql. Backup types include full, differential, incremental, and log backups, enabling complete and point-in-time recovery.

The BACKINT interface allows seamless integration with enterprise backup solutions like Commvault or Veritas. Key configurations such as backup paths and log mode are set in the global.ini file. Regular backups are critical for data protection, system recovery, and ensuring business continuity.

The following are the key configuration parameters for SAP HANA database backups, mainly maintained in the global.ini configuration file.

Parameter

Description

basepath_databackup

Defines the file system path where data backups are stored. E.g., /hana/backup/data

basepath_logbackup

Path where log backups are written. Crucial for point-in-time recovery.

basepath_catalogbackup

(Optional) Path for catalog backups, which store backup history metadata.

log_mode

 Must be set to normal to enable continuous log backups.

enable_auto_log_backup

Enables automatic log backups when set to yes. Prevents log overflow.

catalog_backup_parameter_file

Specifies parameter file for catalog backup behavior, if customized.

log_backup_timeout_s

Time (in seconds) after which an automatic log backup is triggered.

log_backup_interval

(Deprecated in newer versions) Sets interval for periodic log backups.

BACKINT_parameter_file

Points to the configuration file used by third-party tools via BACKINT API.

data_backup_using_BACKINT

If set to true, use BACKINT instead of file-based backup for data.

log_backup_using_BACKINT

If true, redirect log backups through BACKINT to external storage.

 

SAP HANA Backup on BACKINT - BACKINT is an SAP-certified interface that allows third-party backup tools to directly integrate with the SAP HANA database for performing data and log backups, restores, and catalog management.

  • Data Area: Contains columnar and row-store data files (actual business data).
  • Log Area: Contains transaction logs for recovery and redo purposes.
  • BACKINT API: Acts as a connector between SAP HANA and external backup tools. Customization requires a BACKINT agent script provided by the backup vendor.
  • Third Party Tool: Veritas NetBackup, Commvault, Dell EMC Networker, Veeam etc.
  • Backup Storage: Disk, Tapes, AWS S3 and Azure Blob.

 

 

HANA Database and BACKINT Process Flow - HANA Database and BACKINT process flow, which is critical when integrating SAP HANA with third-party backup tools like NetBackup, Commvault, or BACKINT for SAP HANA (AWS BACKINT Agent, Azure Backup, etc.). The following are the HANA database and BACKINT process flow diagram.

             

 

 

       

The following are the advantages and disadvantages of BACKINT Tool-

Advantages of BACKINT in HANA

Disadvantages of BACKIN in HANA

Integration with Enterprise Backup Tools
Supports integration with leading backup solutions (e.g., Veritas NetBackup, Commvault, IBM TSM, etc.), enabling centralized backup management.

Dependency on Third-Party Software
Requires licensed backup tools—can increase costs and introduce vendor lock-in.

Top of Form

 

Bottom of Form

 

No Need for Additional Scripting
Simplifies configuration—no need to manually script backup jobs or maintain local file-based backups.

Complex Configuration
Initial setup and troubleshooting may require expertise in both SAP HANA and the third-party backup software.

 

Direct Backup to External Storage
Data and logs can be backed up directly to external storage or tape libraries, reducing local disk space usage.

Performance Overhead
Backup performance may vary depending on the integration quality and hardware resources.

 

SAP-Certified and Supported
Ensures reliability and compatibility with SAP HANA and adheres to SAP best practices.

Limited Flexibility in Customization
Less customizable compared to script-based file system backups for niche requirements.

 

Secure and Efficient
Supports compression and encryption (depending on the third-party tool) to optimize performance and security.

Restore Time Dependency
Restore performance heavily depends on the third-party backup tool and network/storage performance.

 

Supports Parallel Backup
Allows parallel streams for faster backup and restore operations, especially useful for large databases.

 

 SAP HANA Backup on Local Drive and NFS Drive - To ensure system reliability and disaster recovery preparedness, SAP HANA backups can be configured on both local and NFS storage. This dual approach enhances data protection and ensures recoverability in various failure scenarios.

  • Backup on Local Drive: Backing up SAP HANA to a local drive is the most common and straightforward method. It offers high-speed read/write performance as the data is stored directly on the system’s internal or directly attached storage. Local backups are ideal for daily operational backups and fast recovery processes. However, in the event of disk or server failure, local-only backups may be at risk unless they are replicated elsewhere.

 

  • Backup on NFS Drive: A backup to a Network File System (NFS) drive enables storing data on a remote file server over the network. This method is essential for offsite storage, long-term retention, or disaster recovery planning. Though NFS backups may be slower due to network latency, they offer resilience by storing backups separately from the SAP HANA host. Proper NFS configuration and stable connectivity are critical for consistent backup operations.

 

Aspect

Local Drive

NFS Drive

Backup Path

/hana/backup/data
or any other local drive path.

/mnt/nfs_backup/data

Performance

High-speed, suitable for fast recovery.

Depending on network and NFS server performance.

Configuration

Stored locally on the HANA host.

Stored remotely, safer from host failures.

Disadvantage

Risk if local disk fails, No offsite copy and Limited for DR

Requires network reliability, Slower performance and NFS server must be managed.

Restore Time

Backups restore process in fast.

The backup restore process is slow.

Automation

Easily scriptable, schedule OS crontab or HANA tools.

Same as local ensure NFS is mounted before backup.

Security

Local OS-level access control.

Requires secure NFS access (exports, firewalls)

Use Case

Daily backups and fast restore.

Long-term backups, DR strategy.

SAP HANA Backup on Cloud Storage - SAP HANA backup on cloud storage offers a cost-effective, scalable, and highly durable solution for safeguarding critical business data. By leveraging cloud platforms like AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud, organizations can move away from traditional on-premises storage infrastructure and benefit from flexible, pay-as-you-go models. Cloud storage ensures high availability and geographic redundancy, making it ideal for disaster recovery and long-term retention. SAP HANA supports native backup methods that can be integrated with cloud storage either through mounted cloud file systems or Backint-certified agents provided by cloud vendors. These integrations allow backups to be directly streamed to the cloud without local storage dependency. This approach not only simplifies backup management but also supports compliance with retention policies and enhances the organization’s overall data protection strategy.      

Types of Recovery in HANA Database - SAP HANA recovery is the process of restoring the database to a consistent and operational state after an unexpected failure, data loss, or corruption. It ensures data integrity by using backups and log files to bring the system back to a previous or desired point. Recovery is a critical part of disaster recovery and system maintenance strategies in any SAP HANA environment.

  • Full Recovery – SAP HANA Database Full Recovery is a process used to restore the database to its most recent consistent state after a failure or data loss. It involves recovering the database using a combination of data backups and all available log backups. During full recovery, the system first restores the most recent complete data backup and then replays all subsequent log backups in chronological order to bring the database to the exact point of failure or to a specified timestamp, provided all logs are available. This method ensures minimal data loss and is commonly used in production systems where data integrity and business continuity are critical.

To perform a full recovery, the SAP HANA database must be in a stopped state, and the recovery is typically initiated using the SAP HANA cockpit, HANA Studio, or the command line (HDBSQL). Once the recovery is complete, the system can resume normal operations with the restored data.

 

  • Point-in-Time Recovery - SAP HANA Database Point-in-Time Recovery (PITR) is a process used to restore a database to a specific moment in the past, typically just before an error, data corruption, or unwanted transaction occurred. This type of recovery is essential in scenarios where data consistency needs to be maintained after accidental data deletion or logical corruption.

To perform PITR, we must have a complete data backup along with all the required logs backup up to the desired recovery point. During recovery, SAP HANA replays the logs sequentially from the time of the data backup until the specified point in time. Administrators can define the recovery point based on a timestamp, log position, or specific log backup. PITR helps ensure minimal data loss and business continuity, making it a critical feature in any SAP HANA backup and disaster recovery strategy.

 

  • DB Recovery to Snapshot - HANA Database snapshot recovery is a method used to restore the database to a specific point in time using a previously created data snapshot. A snapshot captures the state of the HANA database at a particular moment, including all relevant data and logs. In the event of data corruption, accidental deletion, or system failure, this snapshot can be used to revert the database back to its saved state, ensuring data consistency and minimizing downtime.

Snapshot recovery is especially useful in test, development, or backup validation scenarios, as it allows fast restoration without the need for a full data backup recovery process. However, it should be noted that snapshot-based recovery does not support point-in-time recovery beyond the snapshot timestamp.

                                          

 

  • HANA Database contains both data and logs.
  • A snapshot is created at a specific timestamp (e.g., 03-22-2024 15:00), capturing the state of the database at that moment.
  • In case of failure or corruption, the Snapshot Recovery process is initiated.
  • The database is then restored to the exact snapshot state, as shown in the Recovered State box at the bottom.
  • This ensures quick system restoration, but only up to the snapshot point — not beyond (i.e., no point-in-time recovery after that snapshot).

SAP HANA Backup Strategies

In today’s digital landscape, data is the lifeline of any business, and SAP HANA, being the core of many enterprise systems, demands a solid and well-planned backup strategy. SAP HANA backup strategies are essential to ensure data integrity, and fast recovery in case of system failures or disasters.

The backup approach in SAP HANA typically includes full data backups, incremental backups, differential backups, and log backups. Full data backups are recommended daily to capture the entire database state, while incremental and differential backups optimize storage and time by saving only changes. Continuous log backups are crucial for point-in-time recovery.

Backups should be automated via SAP HANA Cockpit, HANA Studio, or HDBSQL scripting, and stored in secure, redundant locations such as external NFS shares or cloud storage (e.g., AWS S3 or Azure Blob). It's the best practice to regularly validate backups through test restores, monitor backup status and retention policies, and ensure backup encryption for data security. Integration with third-party backup tools like Commvault, Veritas, or AWS Backint Agent enhances flexibility and compliance. Finally, aligning backup strategies with RTO (Recovery Time Objective) and RPO (Recovery Point Objective) requirements is vital for business continuity. Additionally, SAP backup policies can vary from company based on internal governance, compliance requirements, RTO/RPO expectations, and infrastructure setup. The following is a commonly used, best-practice-based day-wise backup approach for SAP HANA systems.

Day

Backup Type

Details

Daily (24x7)

Log Backups
(Continuous)

- Enabled by default in production systems
- Scheduled to run every 15 minutes or less
- Stored on a dedicated log backup directory
- Crucial for point-in-time recovery (PITR)

Sunday

Full Data Backup

- Captures the entire SAP HANA database state
- Base for differential/incremental backups for the week
- Store on secure external storage (e.g., NFS, S3)

Monday

Differential Backup

- Captures changes since last full backup (Sunday)
- Faster than full, larger than incremental

Tuesday

Incremental Backup

- Captures changes since Monday (last differential)
- Smaller and faster to execute

Wednesday

Differential Backup

- Helps reduce the restore chain complexity compared to incremental-only chains

Thursday

Incremental Backup

- Saves storage and backup time, used with differential strategy

Friday

Differential Backup

- Acts as mid-week near-full image for easier weekend recovery

Saturday

Incremental Backup

 - Final delta before a new full backup cycle begins Sunday

SAP Backup and Restoration Optimization

  • SAP HANA Backup - To optimize SAP HANA database backups, it's essential to adopt a strategy that ensures data protection while minimizing backup duration, storage consumption, and system impact. A well-planned backup approach helps reduce downtime, supports faster recovery during failures, and ensures regulatory compliance. Optimization involves choosing the right backup type, using high-performance storage, enabling parallel processing, and maintaining a regular backup and monitoring routine.

Backup Optimization Points.

  1. Use a combination of full, incremental, and log backups. Example: Weekly full backup + daily incremental + frequent log backups (every 15 mins).
  2. Enable Parallel Backup Processing. Configure max_parallel_backups in global.ini to allow multiple threads to write backups concurrently.
  3. Optimize Backup Storage. Store backups on high-performance storage (e.g., SSD, fast NFS). Avoid using production volumes or over-utilized disks for backups.
  4. Run backups during non-peak hours to avoid performance impact.
  5. Reduce backup size. Use data aging, table partitioning, and archiving to reduce the size of data needing backup.
  6. Validate and Test Backup. Use the BACKUP DATA CHECK command to verify backup consistency. Periodically perform test restores in QA systems to validate recovery procedures.
  • SAP HANA Recover Process - Optimizing the SAP HANA database recovery process is essential to minimize downtime and maintain business continuity. Effective optimization involves strategic preparation, utilizing efficient backup strategies, enhancing storage performance, and ensuring clear recovery documentation and procedures.

Recover Optimization Points

  1. Use Backint Interface, leverage third-party certified Backint solutions to enable faster backup and recovery operations.
  2. Parallel Recovery, enable parallel recovery using the parameter parallel_data_backup_backint_channels to accelerate the recovery process.
  3. Ensure high-speed network connectivity between the backup storage system and the SAP HANA servers to avoid bottlenecks.
  4. Implement HANA System Replication (HSR) for near-instantaneous recovery capability and minimal downtime.
  5. Periodically validate backups to avoid failures during the actual recovery scenario.
  6. Deploy SSD or NVMe storage for storing backups to speed up data throughput and reduce latency.

Thanks,
Abhijeet Chakraborty

entry.title: Re: How schedule line dates and quantities are calculated...
entry.content:
SAP uses a combination of backward scheduling by default, availability check, and MRP data to determine schedule lines. 
1. Requested Delivery Date (RDD)
- Entered manually in the sales order
- Acts as the starting point for scheduling
2. Backward Scheduling
SAP calculates backward from RDD using:
- Transportation lead time
- Loading time
- Picking/packing time
Formula:
Material Availability Date (MAD) = RDD - (Transportation + Loading + Picking)

System checks stock on the Material Availability Date
- If stock is available → Confirmed quantity = Requested quantity
- If not → SAP proposes a new delivery date using forward scheduling

Starts from the earliest possible date when stock is available
- Adds lead times to calculate a new delivery date

Finally, the data is fetched from the below areas

 

SAP first attempts backward scheduling using the requested delivery date (RDD) as the anchor. It subtracts lead times (transportation, loading, picking) to determine the Material Availability Date (MAD). Then it checks stock availability on MAD using ATP (Available-to-Promise).
- If stock is available → the system confirms the RDD and creates a schedule line.
- If stock is NOT available → SAP switches to forward scheduling.

entry.title: Re: Functional Location Structure Indicator Issue while d...
entry.content:
Possible Causes of Structure Indicator Mismatches are
Missing or Incorrect Structure Indicator Configuration. The structure indicator must be predefined in Customizing before loading data. If the indicator used in the template doesn't match what's configured in the system (edit mask, hierarchy levels), SAP may default to a different one or reject the format.
Even if the hierarchy levels look fine, the edit mask (which controls allowed characters and grouping) might differ. For example, a mask like AA-AA-AA vs. AAA-AA-AA will cause mismatches.
Structure indicators are managed at the client level, so if you're working across systems or clients, the indicator might not exist or be different in the target system.
If you're using reference functional locations, the system may apply the structure indicator from the reference instead of the one in your template.
Sometimes the field mapping in the Migration Cockpit doesn’t correctly link the structure indicator field to the backend table, especially if custom fields or enhancements are involved.

What You Can Do
- Double-check the structure indicator configuration in SPRO > Plant Maintenance and Customer Service > Master Data > Technical Objects > Functional Locations > Create Structure Indicator. There
- Verify that the edit mask and hierarchy levels match exactly between the template and system config.
- Ensure the structure indicator exists and is active in the target system/client.
- If needed, manually create or adjust the structure indicator before reloading the data.

entry.title: Exploring the Fundamentals of Setting up and Running SAP Commerce Cloud in a B2B Environment
entry.content:
I'm Charis from SAP CX Product Learning team and I am happy to share some exciting news for SAP Commerce Cloud business users, consultants, and sales professionals! A brand-new learning journey has arrived on learning.sap.com:

Exploring the Fundamentals of Setting up and Running SAP Commerce Cloud in a B2B Environment

What's in it for you?

  • Business Users: Discover how SAP Commerce Cloud can streamline your B2B operations, enhance customer experiences, and drive sales growth. Learn key functionalities and explore practical applications for your specific business needs.
  • Consultants: Expand your expertise and gain a competitive edge by mastering the intricacies of SAP Commerce Cloud for B2B implementations. This learning journey will equip you with the knowledge and skills to deliver successful client projects.
  • Sales Professionals: Strengthen your sales pitches and confidently articulate the value proposition of SAP Commerce Cloud for B2B customers. Understand the platform's capabilities and effectively address client needs.

After completing this learning journey, the learner will be able to:

  • Construct the merchant sales organization including users and spend thresholds.
  • Reproduce the customer purchasing organization in the My Company Section of SAP Commerce Cloud.
  • Employ the storefront order process, including cart assembly, checkout, approval and quote negotiations. 
  • Describe that integrated buying is supported in SAP Commerce Cloud via Punchout support.

The learning journey consists of 4 units:

  • Setting up the Merchant Organization and Customer Specific Thresholds:This unit teaches you how to replicate a sales organization within SAP Commerce Cloud, connect it to various customer purchasing organizations, and configure credit limits and quote negotiation thresholds.
     
  • Managing the Customer Sales Organization in SAP Commerce Cloud: This unit teaches you how to set up a customer's purchasing structure within SAP Commerce Cloud, including configuring user roles and purchase limits, and managing cost centers and budgets.
  • Purchasing and Selling on the SAP Commerce Cloud B2B Storefront: This unit covers the B2B storefront ordering process in SAP Commerce Cloud, from exploring ordering options and negotiating quotes to navigating the checkout process and managing order approvals.
  • Pairing SAP Commerce Cloud with Procurement Systems using Punchout: This unit explains how SAP Commerce Cloud supports integrated buying through PunchOut functionality.

The learning journey contains very informative content provided in text, diagrams, videos. At the end of each unit, you will be called to answer on quiz questions which will test your understanding on the topic.

The Learning Journey is available for everyone and it's free! Complete this learning journey and earn a verifiable SAP Authorized Badge on your learning profile!

entry.title: Re: Post Depreciation on last period only
entry.content: Solely at asset class level, it cannot be controlled. However, in your asset class, assign depreciation key - Z7512 as a default. So, while Asset Class helps default the logic, the actual Period 12-only behavior must be embedded in the depreciation key and depreciation area setup.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Series Finale: Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead
entry.content:
After eight powerful sessions, the “Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Journey – From Data to Intelligence” webinar series came to a close on July 25th with an inspiring final chapter: “SAP BDC Series Wrap-Up – Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead.”

As someone deeply involved in enterprise architecture at SAP, I didn’t just watch this series as an internal stakeholder. I experienced it like many of you — trying to understand how we move forward, how we transform data from. a static asset into a living, breathing foundation for innovation. This wasn’t just about technology. It was about possibility.   This closing session wasn’t just the end of a series — it felt like a milestone in a journey many of us have been walking together. 

Moderated by Paul Kurchina and joined by visionary voices like Prakash Nanduri, Timo Elliott, Ralph Richter, and Gaurish Dessai, the session offered far more than a recap. It brought clarity on where we are — and where we’re heading next.

After eight weeks of listening, learning, questioning, and connecting, one thing is clear: Business Data Cloud is no longer just a concept. It’s something we’re actively building, together.

So instead of a simple summary, I want to share a few personal reflections — the moments that stayed with me, the insights that truly resonated, and the themes I believe will shape the next chapter in our data journey.

Why SAP Business Data Cloud?

When Prakash Nanduri spoke, it was more than a product overview — it was a mission statement. Prakash, a long-time entrepreneur and now back at SAP, shared how BDC isn’t just another SAP initiative. It’s about transforming the core of how businesses use data.

“SAP has automated business processes for 50 years,” Prakash said. “Now it’s time to make the data from those processes the engine for the next generation of intelligence.”

Here’s what BDC is really about: The “Why” Behind BDC:

  1. Harmonizing SAP and non-SAP data so that AI, analytics, planning, and predictive models have a clean, reliable foundation.
  2. Creating consistent, connected processes across SAP applications — from S/4HANA to Ariba, SuccessFactors, and more.

Five Guiding Principles of SAP Business Data Cloud

What makes BDC different? It’s not just a product. It’s a strategy, rooted in five key principles:

  1. Persona-Centric Design: BDC is built for specific users — data engineers, analysts, scientists, developers, and business decision-makers. Every feature, every integration is designed to help someone do their job better.
  2. Modern Lakehouse Architecture: BDC acts as the unified data lake for SAP — but it plays well with others. It integrates with platforms like Databricks, Azure, and BigQuery using open file formats like Parquet and protocols like Delta Lake.
  3. The Data product: One of the most exciting innovations is the data product — a combination of metadata, data, and an API wrapper that allows zero-copy, governed sharing. These aren’t just generic objects — they’re tied to your SAP instance, with your extensions, running on the cloud provider of your choice.
  4. End to End Tooling : BDC brings together tools like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, BW/4HANA PCE, and SAP Databricks — making it possible to go from raw data to models to intelligent apps in a seamless flow.
  5. Open Data Exchange: This isn’t about locking you in. It’s about sharing and subscribing to data across SAP and non-SAP systems — using open standards, securely and efficiently.

Five Guiding Principles of SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP BDC as the Fabric of Enterprise Data

Another key theme that stood out was SAP BDC’s role in a data fabric architecture.

“A data fabric connects SAP and non-SAP data with semantics, metadata, observability, and governance — without needing to centralize it all.” – Prakash Nanduri

Instead of duplicating data across lakes and warehouses, BDC helps you leave the data where it is — while making it usable across all your use cases. With BDC as a data fabric, you get:

  • Federated access to SAP and third-party data
  • Built-in semantics and metadata to make data understandable
  • Lineage and observability for trust and traceability
  • Real-time APIs to power apps, AI, and analytics

This model is key for large enterprises that need agility without sacrificing control — and BDC makes that a reality.

Continue our path towards a Business Data Fabric

Rapid Innovation, Tangible Progress

Here’s what really stood out: BDC isn’t just an idea on paper. It’s live. It's growing. And it's delivering.

  • Over 130 SAP-generated data products are already available. We expect 470+ by end of 2025.
  • New intelligent applications like People Intelligence are live and built entirely on BDC.
  • Databricks integration means data scientists can use Jupiter notebooks with live SAP data, securely and efficiently.
  • BW modernization now allows BW data to be accessed in Parquet format — unlocking new value without heavy lifting.

These aren’t future promises. They’re things you and I can start working with today.

Listening to the Community: What You Told Us

Another highlight for me was when Timo Elliott walked us through the live feedback from our community. What’s holding organizations back from using their data more effectively?

  • Complexity
  • Lack of context
  • Poor quality and integration
  • Difficulty accessing the right data

And what do people want from SAP and other vendors? 

  • Less marketing, more clarity
  • Tools that are hands-on and simple
  • Open standards and real-world use cases
  • Broader AI accessibility

Timo said something that stayed with me:  “Data quality is never just a technical issue — it’s often a symptom of broken business processes.”.  That’s a truth we need to keep repeating. Tools can only go so far if we don’t also look at the organizational habits behind them.

The Questions Everyone’s Asking

Gaurish Dessai jumped in to answer the three most frequently asked questions throughout the series — and he answered them with precision:

  • Where can I find SAP’s data products?
    → Check out the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. There’s now a dedicated section for data products.
  • What intelligent applications are available or coming?
    → Already live: Working Capital, People Intelligence
    → Coming soon: Finance, Customer, Supply Chain, and Spend Intelligence
  • Where can I see what’s being launched next?
    → Visit the SAP Product Roadmap Explorer and search for “Business Data Cloud”

If you haven’t bookmarked those resources, I highly recommend you do.

What’s Coming Next?

Ralph Richter gave us a look at the future — and it’s full of opportunities:

  • Free trials and BDC assessments are now available
  • Community events are expanding, including: 
    • SAP + IBM Enterprise Architecture Dialog – Sept 8, London
    • SAP Enterprise Architecture Summit – Oct 7–9, Berlin
    • SAP Multidimensional Architect Program – Oct, San Ramon

These aren’t just events — they’re collaborative experiences focused on the human and technical skills architects need to thrive now.

One Big Takeaway

As we closed the session, Paul asked the panel: “What’s your one big takeaway?”

  • Gaurish Dessai: “There’s never been a better time to be a Data Architect.”
  • Timo Elliott: “BDC is the foundation — not just for data, but for everything we do with AI in the future.”
  • Paul Kurchina: “This is a journey we’re on — and we’re on it together, as a community.”

My Reflection

As an Enterprise Architect at SAP, this series has been a meaningful checkpoint in how we think about the future of data architecture. What stood out to me is that SAP Business Data Cloud isn’t just a new platform — it represents a strategic shift in how we deliver business value through data.  The move toward data products — harmonized, reusable, and ready for AI — changes the game. It challenges us to stop thinking in silos and start thinking in ecosystems. It's not just about integration anymore; it’s about orchestration across people, platforms, and processes.

BDC gives us the architectural clarity to do what we’ve always aimed for: simplify complexity, scale intelligence, and empower business users — without compromising governance or trust. In many ways, this moment reminds us that architecture is no longer just about systems — it's about enabling possibility.

entry.title: Influencing posting price at GR with BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE
entry.content:
Hi there.

We are trying to influence the material price when posting a goods receipt with BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE.
Therefore we are using the field AMOUNT_LC of structure GOODSMVT_ITEM. 

According to it"s documentation (BAPI_EXBWR) this field can be used for

"The value of the movement is calculated automatically by the system. However, it is possible to enter an amount manually if the item is to be valuated at a different price."

But is seems this documentation is not accurate, since when we are setting a different price in structure GOODSMVT_ITEM-AMOUNT_LC only MSEG-EXBWR gets updated with this, but not MSEG-DMBTR which is the base for the valuation of the material document. 
Is it really possible to influence the price with field AMOUNT_LC in BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE?
Maybe someone made the same experience and has a solution for it
Somehow the documentation of  BAPI_EXBWR seems to be misleading.

Thank you very much in advance
Best regards

Heinz

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What’s New as of 2025-08-04?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

It’s great to be back with another round of exciting updates. August brought some fresh changes to the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model, and I’m here to walk you through what’s new.

Let’s jump right in and explore the highlights!

Environment screen

For users accessing the User Guide or reporting an incident, Built-in Support from SAP is now available directly in your tenants.
With this update, not only can you still access the User Guide and report incidents, but you can now also navigate to the SAP Community directly from the application.
As a result, the previous Help option will be replaced by this new built-in support experience.

For more information, please visit Integrated Support Experience: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model with SAP Built-in Support.

Modeling screen

Good news for modelers!
To improve efficiency, the Activate button on the Modeling screen now comes with extended functionality - it will first save any changes made to the modeling configuration and then proceed with activation, just like how it works in SAP PaPM On-Premise version.

Report Management screen | Chat with AI copilot - Joule

A new feature in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model has been enhanced in the Settings and Report Management screens to enable AI-powered insights via Joule.
To start using Joule in the application, some initial setup is required in SAP BTP. These steps are described in the SAP Business AI (Joule) Setup.
After the setup, simply go to the Settings screen and, under the new “Joule AI Settings” section, select your SAP AI Core destination and choose the AI model you want to use.

Once configured, Joule becomes available in the Report Management screen, allowing users to ask questions about the report and receive instant answers from AI.

More details on how to configure Joule in SAP BTP and how to use it later in the Report Management screen can be found in the SAP PaPM Cloud blog post SAP PaPM Cloud SM: Enhancing Report Management with the power of generative AI copilot – Joule, or by visiting our Application Help portal SAP Business AI (Joule) Setup.

Administration | Settings screen

Administrators and modelers can now add additional mapping fields to their Remote Function Adapters using the new RFA template. To do this, simply navigate to the Settings screen and select Customize RFA Template.

For more information, please refer to Application Help portal Modeling Settings or visit SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model - RFA's field customization feature.

Administration | Content Management screen

To help administrators avoid accidental overwrites, the Content Management screen now displays a warning message when the “Overwrite” option is set to “Yes”, alerting users that changes from the current environment version will be lost.

That wraps up this month’s round of updates! Hopefully, these new features make your day-to-day work a little smoother.
Stay tuned, stay engaged, and see you in the next one!

entry.title: Stock not transferred from ROD storage location after SMQ2 error solving
entry.content:
We have a SAP S4 set-up with embedded EWM. We have a ROD (received on dock) storage location and an AFS (available for sale) storage location in our EWM. So as long as the putaway warehouse tasks aren't confirmed, the stock remains in the ROD storage location. When we then confirm the warehouse tasks, the stock is moved with a transfer order and movement type 411 automatically to storage location AFS. 

When something goes wrong on the inbound flow, and we need to reprocess an inbound delivery that got stuck in the SMQ2 error queue (note that we solve the error queue, and not just save the LUW to SMQ3!), we experience that our automatic 411 transfer from the ROD storage location to the AFS storage location does not happen anymore. Probably because the warehouse tasks that trigger it, had already been confirmed. 

Does anyone have any experience in how to solve this?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to Check Storefront's IPs and IP Range
entry.content:
Dear Customer,
I hope you are doing well.

To find the public IP address for your SAP Commerce Cloud environment, follow these steps:

  1. Open the Cloud Portal home page.
  2. Navigate to the environment details page for your desired Commerce Cloud environment.
  3. Click on an endpoint's name to access the "Edit Endpoint" page.
  4. The public IP address is shown in the web proxy field in the General Information section.

Please note that the public IP is consistent across all public endpoints within the environment.

Kind regards,
Bárbara
SAP Support
